article.title: Spatial regulation of a common precursor from two distinct genes generates metabolite diversity†
article.abstract: In secondary metabolite biosynthesis, core synthetic genes such as polyketide synthase genes usually encode proteins that generate various backbone precursors. These precursors are modified by other tailoring enzymes to yield a large variety of different secondary metabolites. The number of core synthesis genes in a given species correlates, therefore, with the number of types of secondary metabolites the organism can produce.

sections.introduction: Filamentous fungi, such as species found within the genus Aspergillus, are well known producers of secondary metabolites (SMs) with interesting biological activities.
sections.methods: Primers used in this study are listed in Table S1.† The fungal strains used in this study are listed in Table S2.† The scheme for heterologously expressing the NRPS-like genes of A. terreus in A. nidulans is shown in Fig. S1.†
sections.results: Using a recently reported efficient heterologous expression (HE) system in A. nidulans,9 the individual NRPS-like genes identified in the A. terreus genome were expressed at either the wA or yA locus of A. nidulans under regulation of the inducible alcA promoter (Fig. S1A†).
sections.discussion: Our study suggests that metabolite diversity can be expanded by spatial regulation of the same precursor biosynthesized by two distinct genes.

article.insights_summary: Our study reveals that metabolite diversity can be expanded by spatial regulation of the same precursor biosynthesized by two distinct genes.
